Opened in1904 as People’s Drug Store, in 1957, it changed to Hamlin Drug Store and was in business for approximately 107 years. The pharmacy offered a lifeline to obtain critical medicine for people across Wake County and North Carolina.
This #BlackHistoryMonth, I’m highlighting James Edward Hamlin, the owner of the oldest drug store in Raleigh, and the oldest African American owned pharmacy in North Carolina.

A full investigation is needed to determine why ERCOT & other state agencies did not act or communicate sooner. Regulations & emergency funding should be put in place to allow power generation companies to take temporary steps like Vistra did to prevent another tragic breakdown.

If this company knew this, ERCOT must have known even without Vistra's warning but the Texas public was not given any communication about how severe the coming storm, cold temperatures, and power emergency would be.

When their meteorologist saw temperatures well below 10 degrees, the company told me they alerted state officials to the possibility of power generating units going offline, knowing that our state's power infrastructure couldn't withstand temperatures much less than 10 degrees.

Vistra took commonsense emergency steps like space heaters, putting up temporary walls to block the wind, and running a hot wire to keep their pipes from freezing. By taking these steps, their share of the total Texas grid went from 18 to 30%.

Since then, I've been working to get answers for North Texans and wanted to give an update. North Texas based Vistra Corporation officials told me that by February 9th they knew this storm was coming and alerted ERCOT and state officials who then failed to respond urgently.

Earlier this week, I posted 4 questions I had while on a call with ERCOT that I thought Texans deserved answers to—particularly about why generation units weren't prepared for the storm and why the agency’s projections for peak use were so far off.
